3. Applications may be submitted by any bona fide univer¬
sity, college, school system or other accredited educational
institution, or NAEB Active or Associate member, though
no preference will be given to NAEB members.
4. Individual grants will not exceed $7,000.00. Applications
asking for considerably less than this maximum amount
will receive full consideration. No grant will include funds
for capital expenditures.
5. By definition, grants-in-aid cannot carry the full burden
of production costs (they are intended to help educational
broadcasters to help themselves). As an example, a grantee
may thus be enabled to employ a key person or otherwise
strengthen or supplement local resources to make the pro¬
duction possible or outstanding.
6. All programs produced under these grants must be suitable
for use on the NAEB Radio Network.
7. Full radio rights to the programs and television rights to
idea, format and script, must be obtained for all program
materials included; these rights become the property of
the Educational Television and Radio Center.
8. Applications must be in writing. Six copies of all written
material and exhibits must be supplied, together with a
statement of the staff and facilities available for the project
and a pilot program on tape.
9. Grants will be made on the basis of these applications;
thus completeness and understandability of presentation
are vital.
10. Deadline for applications is May 1, 1958; all applications
must be received at NAEB headquarters or post-marked by
that date. The announcement of grants will be on June 15,
1958.
11. Production of all projects must start 90 days after the grant
is made, unless, as shall be clearly explained in the appli¬
cation, a valid reason exists for a later starting date. In this
case an extension to not over 120 days from date of grant
may be authorized.
